journal-title-group.journal-title: American journal of medical genetics. Part A

title-group.article-title: Two Angelman Families with Unusually Advanced Neurodevelopment Carry a Start Codon Variant in the Most Highly Expressed UBE3A Isoform

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Psychiatry, Boston Children’s Hospital, MA

author-notes.corresp: Corresponding Authors: Anjali Sadhwani, Department of Psychiatry, Boston Children’s Hospital, 300 Longwood Avenue, Boston, MA 02115, Anjali.sadhwani@childrens.harvard.edu, Phone: 617-919-3495, Fax: 617-730-0962; Wen-Hann Tan, Division of Genetics and Genomics, Boston Children’s Hospital, 300 Longwood Avenue, Boston, MA 02115, wen-hann.tan@childrens.harvard.edu, Tel: 617-355 6394, Fax: 617-730 0466

fn.p: These authors contributed equally to this work.

abstract.p: We present three children from two unrelated families with Angelman syndrome (AS) whose developmental skills are far more advanced than any other non-mosaic AS individual ever reported. All have normal gait and use syntactic language spontaneously to express their needs. All of them have a c.2T>C (p.Met1Thr) variant in UBE3A, which abrogates the start codon of isoform 1, but not of isoforms 2 and 3. This variant was maternally-inherited in one set of siblings, but de novo in the other child from the unrelated family. This report underscores the importance of considering AS in the differential diagnosis even in the presence of syntactic speech.
